title.gco:CharacterString: Hydrographic Features (Polygons): United States and Territories, 2011

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: United States. Bureau of the Census. Geography Division
United States. Bureau of Transportation Statistics

deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: United States. Department of Transportation. Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: United States. Bureau of Transportation Statistics

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Compiled by the University of Tennessee Center for Transportation Research GIS GROUP from the TIGER/Line machine readable files, U.S. Bureau of the Census (BOC)

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This polygon shapefile depicts hydrography coverages that were created using TIGER/Line 2000 shapefile data gathered from ESRI's Geography Network. The individual county hydrography polyline shapefiles were processed into Arc/Info coverages and then appended together to create complete state coverages. They were then edited to remove unwanted features, leaving a state-by-state database of both important and navigable water features. Attributes were added to denote navigable features and names. Also, an attribute was added to the polygons to denote which were water and which were land features. The state databases were then appended together to create a single, nationwide hydrography network containing named arcs and polygons. These features also contain a state Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS). Because some of the hydro features are represented by lines instead of polygons, the complete hydro dataset consists of 2 shapefiles, one for lines and one for polygons. They must be used together to present a complete picture. This layer is part of the 2014 National Transportation Atlas Database.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: The National Transportation Atlas Databases 2014 (NTAD2014) is a set of nationwide geographic datasets of transportation facilities, transportation networks, associated infrastructure and other political and administrative entities. These datasets include spatial information for transportation modal networks and intermodal terminals, as well as the re¬lated attribute information for these features. This data supports research, analysis, and decision-making across all transportation modes. It is most useful at the national level, but has major applications at regional, state and local scales throughout the transportation community. The data used to compile NTAD2014 was provided by our partners within the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) and by other agencies throughout the United States Federal Government. These contributors are the actual data stewards and are ultimately responsible for the maintenance and accuracy of their data. This data was developed because the Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) wants a single nationwide database that has polygons/attributes for major rivers and lakes, is consistent across state lines and has the most accurate data available. This database will be used primarily for map production, basic queries and will be distributed as part of the National Transportation Atlas Databases (NTAD) 2014.

credit.gco:CharacterString: United States. Department of Transportation. Research and Innovative Technology Administration. (2014). Hydrographic Features (Polygons): United States and Territories, 2011. National Transportation Atlas Database 2014. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/jx308gf9049.

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1.4959

supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The BTS HYDRO Database contains TIGER 2000 geometry and attributes. UTCTR flagged this database to represent major water features and edited the geometry to insure polygons would fill for cartographic representation. To find out more about TIGER/Line files and other Census TIGER data base derived data sets visit http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger.

title.gco:CharacterString: Feature catalog for Hydrographic Features (Polygons): United States and Territories, 2011

evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: All node-link and polygon topological relationships are created and verified using computer algorithms. Unique entity identifiers were similarly verified by computer algorithm.

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: All node-link and polygon topological relationships are created and verified using computer algorithms. Unique entity identifiers were similarly verified by computer algorithm.
Attributes for the hydrography data set were created using ARC/INFO, a Geographic Information System. All area and distance values were calculated to the nearest 50m.

description.gco:CharacterString: When UTN processed the TIGER dataset for State, County and Hydrographic (lines and polygons), a 3-mile buffer was created around the Texas shorelines. This buffer removed the island off the coast of Texas. To correct this error, BTS used ARC/INFO to remove the 3-mile buffer to capture the islands along Texas. To capture the islands, the state dataset needed to be reselected by selecting: code = 1. This process created a few inaccurate polygons and they were removed. To create the final datasets, the datasets were dissolved and regions created on STFIPS and County FIPS.

1) Downloaded zipped shapefiles from www.geographynetwork.com; 2) Converted the Shapefiles to Coverages; 3) Removed all intermittent water features H02, H12, H22, H32, H42, H60, H71, H72, H80, and H81 from the database coverages; 4) Flagged arcs to be retained in the output coverage based on relative importance and research using the Internet and state maps; 5) Added attributes to polygons to denote name description and land/water. These attributes were then populated by user input using mapping resources such as state and county maps; 6) Added attribute to both arcs and polygons to denote navigable waterways. For single line features, the arcs were flagged. If a feature contained polygons, the polygons only were flagged; 7) States were then appended, extra items dropped, data released.
